context_left: ### Last Time in the BEC Taxonomy Series… Proofpoint researchers in the [sixth](/us/blog/threat-insight/bec-taxonomy-gift-carding "BEC Taxonomy: Gift Carding ") of the [Business Email Compromise](/us/threat-reference/business-email-compromise "Business Email Compromise (BEC)") (BEC) taxonomy series explored the gift carding theme from the
context_right: Taxonomy framework (Figure 1). Gift carding is a fairly common form of email fraud that relies heavily on familiarity and, like the final theme we will explore, a sense of urgency to override any hesitation on the part of the victims to get them to fall for the fraud.

sentence_left: ### Last Time in the BEC Taxonomy Series…
sentence_right: Gift carding is a fairly common form of email fraud that relies heavily on familiarity and, like the final theme we will explore, a sense of urgency to override any hesitation on the part of the victims to get them to fall for the fraud.
label: Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns. Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source.

Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source.
